ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The basics of American sign language
I learned a lot of basic signing skills and about Deaf culture and identity.

In only a semester, I feel that I have become fairly competent in conversational ASL. We covered a broad variety of signs throughout the course which help us talk about school, hobbies, and family. The course also taught me so much about Deaf culture and art around the world that I otherwise would have never been exposed to.
Basic ASL communicative skills and Deaf awareness.
I gained a basic understanding of deaf culture and extensive beginning knowledge of ASL. I feel confident in carrying a novice conversation in ASL.
Besides learning basic signs, I learned about Deaf culture and the challenges faced by Deaf/Hard of hearing people.
I learned an incredible amount about ASL and the Deaf community.
Basics of ASL, Deaf culture, 5 parameters of ASL
I developed the ability to begin conversational ASL. I can answer simple questions and explain directions. I am also able to tell others about creating a more accessible world through Deaf Culture.
I learned about deaf culture and how to communicate with deaf people through sign language. I learned how to tell stories, give directions, explain how I feel, ask questions, and many more things.
200+ sign language vocabulary, grammar/structure, learned about the deaf/HoH community and participated in service projects relating to these communities.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: 
-Very immersive, steep learning curve.
-Lots of time to practice in class with conversations with prof, peers, etc.

Weaknesses:
-The service project is a great idea, but we were not given nearly enough guidance about how to do it well. It was very difficult to navigate the service project, and as a result, I think most people feel they did not accomplish very much.

Strengths - small class and great community. The ASL community at Yale is incredible; coming to class most days of the week made our section especially close. I often find myself signing with others outside of class for fun or teaching our friends in our free time.

Weaknesses - The online signing assignments were a good practice toolwhich did end up being useful throughout the course, but sometimes they were incredibly tedious and boring. They were also graded for credit and not completion, which was incredibly frustrating when you would spend 30 minutes doing an assignment just to miss the last question (which sometimes used vocabulary we did not learn in class) and you would have to redo the entire assignment. Certainly not a dealbreaker for this incredible course, just kind of annoying.

This course is very strong in providing scaffolding for new learners of ASL. I also had a great time with joint classeswhere we got to have conversations with students from other sections at the same time as ourswhich I thought were very conducive to learning. The service component is important for an ASL class too, I think. My problems with this class were in organizationit seemed like there were a lot of attempts to standardize between classes and instructors that didnt work/werent appropriate to learning needs/overly complicated our lives. There were so many documents and rubrics and files within files that it was personally inaccessible for me. My instructor did a good job handling this, but it was frustrating.

I think that a strength of the course is the immersion in asl and the involvement in the Deaf community. I think that a weakness of the course is that it is hard to go back and review the class material if you cannot remember a sign. I think this could be improved by recording pieces of class.

Class is super engaging and reminds me of my love for learning; full immersion and the integration of Deaf culture/service projects are huge strengths; Not being able to write down vocab/notes/watch back the class makes it harder to remember all the vocab we've learned which is a definite weakness

This class reaches far beyond the classroom in engaging students in service projects. This is a definite plus!
Some assignments were a bit vague in directionality which was a little tough, but all instructors were easy to contact.
I do not think there is anything that needs to improve in this course. It was very well taught and I really liked my teacher.

The hardest part of this course is the lack of spoken language. I found it challenging at times to learn on my own and even with a tutor, learning was difficult. Not being able to talk to other students in class made it an impossibility to really get to know one's class mates and develop study groups. I think organizing a section or outside meetings is an absolute necessity for success in this coursetutors are not enough practice. The instructor of this course was excellent and she helped me out when I was struggling with learning the language. I met with her on a handful of occasions, exchanged emails, and in each of these interactions a learned a lot. It's my belief that Dr. Rubin is an excellent instructor.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Every student at Yale should take ASL.
Yes -- I think learning ASL should be much more common for students. Despite some of the logistical challenges of the course, I learned a TON!
YES!
Absolutely. the ASL faculty and community at Yale are incredible.
Yes, ASL is a great language to know!
Yes one thousand percent. It is a very engaging class and the department is a loving community. I loved the class.
Yes, I would recommend this class to anyone looking to take a fun language class. I had a great time and all of the professors are really enthusiastic about the material.
I would because I had an incredible time and I learned a ton.

YES-- it's a great language to learn and makes you a lot more aware of issues surrounding inclusivity; the ASL department overall is super strong and I don't know anyone taking ASL who doesn't love the class and their teacher
Absolutely! I loved my time in this course. I was using it as a language requirement, yet I am super excited to return for L2.
I would recommend this course to another student because I liked the way it was formatted. I really liked the instructor.

I would recommend American Sign Language to those interested in learning the language. Even though I found that the language wasn't for me, Dr. Rubin was an excellent instructor and took an interest in ensuring her students were engaged with the class and were performing well. The class is fun at the beginning, but later in the semester as vocabulary expands and more rules are taught, the language get much more difficult to learn as there are many signs to memorize and recognize throughout the course. All in all I enjoyed the course.
